guidelines: {"blocks":[{"key":"47tc3","text":"OBJECTIVE","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cks8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d286q","text":"To document the field processes for collecting hematophagous leeches (Family Hirudinea).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":77,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1dl6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6er6u","text":"SUMMARY/SCOPE","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":13}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"77tb1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4gh5b","text":"The overarching aim of the REDI-NET is to develop a collaborative laboratory network between domestic and international partnering institutions to address disease surveillance needs in order to effectively detect, predict and contain potentially emergent zoonosis. status.info: We use this protocol and it's working

steps.section: SAMPLING TEAMS
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"8rqrt","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aa21r","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"eodbq","text":"Field sampling of iDNA (leech) samples involves two people. One person serves as the ‘sampler’ and the other person serves as a ‘helper’. The helper can look up details in these instructions when needed, keep track of samples, handle objects that are contamination risks, serve as a second set of eyes for potential contamination, and ensure safety of the sampler in potentially hazardous field conditions.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":4,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"9g0lv","text":"NOTE: Suggested sampling frequency at each site is one time per month or, when not logistically possible, at minimum two times per unique season representative of the  laboratory setting (e.g., early wet/ late wet; early dry/late dry; rainy/ dry season).","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: SAMPLING SITE SELECTION
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"41rr1","text":"Find two suitable sampling locations within the water body representing different ecological systems, if possible.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: SAMPLING SITE SELECTION
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"2iubm","text":"At each sampling location, leech traps should be placed in triplicate at least 10-20 meters apart from the water and sediment sample collection point, and each trap should be distant by 5 meters from each other.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: LEECH TRAPPING
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"f3tes","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8vsrq","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"7941h","text":"After identifying sample sites location in the water body, deploy the leech traps. Place a stake in the water body or flag a tree to indicate the sampling site location.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c5abr","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"aq3pf","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":4,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"fv9hu","text":"NOTE: Leech traps should be constructed and prepared ahead of time, and baited with\nfresh liver on site.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":79,"offset":1,"style":"bold"}],"key":"9t0c1","text":" Leech trapping should be conducted prior to water, sediment, and tick sampling.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: LEECH TRAPPING
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"6uok","text":"Insert a piece of liver into the prepared traps, as instructed in Appendix 1. Leech Traps Construction (see Figures 1 and 2). Attach fishing line to trap and tie the remaining end around the flagged tree or stake to enable trap recovery.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: LEECH TRAPPING
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"evvat","text":"Use nearby rocks to weigh the leech trap when placing it in water to ensure full submersion.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: LEECH TRAPPING
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"396vc","text":"Repeat steps 4 - 6 to place traps at the second sampling location in the water body.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: LEECH TRAPPING
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"75cjb","text":"Check traps after 2–3 hours (after completing tick/water and soil collections).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: LEECH TRAPPING
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"f3of2","text":"Recover traps and carefully open to expose the liver bait. Using forceps, check each side of the liver for leeches. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"29g4k","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"76l2k","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":4,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"9tl8e","text":"NOTE: All leeches should be collected from each trap and should be placed into one large container with water from their original environment by sampling location (see step 10).","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: LEECH TRAPPING
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"8d7v3","text":"Leeches can gently be removed from the liver bait with tweezers and placed directly into the large (example size  ) pre-labeled field transport container with water collected from their original environment. steps.section: LEECH TRAPPING
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"52esh","text":"Place all labeled storage containers into a cooler with ice until arriving back to the lab to prevent active swimming during transport; which promotes the consumption of the blood-meal.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: LEECH TRAPPING

steps.section: LEECH STORAGE
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"9cnrg","text":"Keep freshly collected leeches alive in glass jars which allow air passage (net-lidded or lids with multiple holes) and two-thirds filled with source water and tightly packed (so they will not spill) in a   cold chain (cooler box), ensuring air movement until return to laboratory.
